metadata.description: Scenario-Based Study Companion for cloud computing fundamentals - covers IaaS/PaaS/SaaS, cloud benefits, GCP resource hierarchy, regions/zones, billing, IAM basics, and core services overview.

question.title: Cloud Computing Definition
question.scenario: A small business currently runs all applications on physical servers in their office. They are considering moving to cloud computing but want to understand what it actually means.
question.question-text: What is the primary characteristic that defines cloud computing?

choices.choice: On-demand delivery of IT resources over the internet with pay-as-you-go pricing
Purchasing servers and installing them in your own datacenter
Using only free and open-source software
Connecting multiple office computers in a local network

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud computing provides resources on-demand without owning physical infrastructure.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud computing is the on-demand delivery of computing resources (servers, storage, databases, networking, software) over the internet with pay-as-you-go pricing. You access resources when needed without purchasing hardware.

ul.li: NIST defines five essential characteristics: on-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling, rapid elasticity, and measured service.
Cloud eliminates the need for upfront capital investment in hardware.
Resources are provisioned in minutes rather than weeks or months.

question.title: IaaS Service Model
question.scenario: A company wants to migrate their existing applications to the cloud but needs full control over the operating system, middleware, and runtime environment.
question.question-text: Which cloud service model provides virtualized computing resources where you manage the OS and everything above it?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IaaS gives you virtual machines where you control the operating system and above.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) provides virtualized computing resources. The cloud provider manages the physical hardware, networking, and virtualization layer. You manage the OS, middleware, runtime, and applications. Google Compute Engine is a GCP IaaS offering.

ul.li: IaaS offers maximum flexibility and control over the computing environment.
You are responsible for patching, security updates, and OS configuration.
Best for lift-and-shift migrations of existing applications.
GCP IaaS includes Compute Engine VMs, persistent disks, and VPC networking.

question.title: PaaS Service Model
question.scenario: A development team wants to deploy a web application without worrying about server management, OS patching, or infrastructure scaling.
question.question-text: Which cloud service model allows developers to focus only on their application code while the provider manages the underlying platform?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: PaaS handles the platform; you just deploy your code.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Platform as a Service (PaaS) provides a complete development and deployment environment. The provider manages servers, OS, middleware, and runtime. Developers focus on writing and deploying application code. Google App Engine is a GCP PaaS offering.

ul.li: PaaS reduces operational overhead and accelerates development cycles.
Built-in scaling, load balancing, and health management.
GCP PaaS includes App Engine, Cloud Run, and Cloud Functions.
Trade-off: Less control over infrastructure in exchange for simplicity.

question.title: SaaS Service Model
question.scenario: A marketing team needs email and document collaboration tools but does not want to install or maintain any software on their computers.
question.question-text: Which cloud service model delivers complete software applications over the internet that users access through a web browser?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: SaaS delivers ready-to-use software applications over the internet.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Software as a Service (SaaS) provides complete applications hosted and managed by the provider. Users access them via web browsers without installation. Google Workspace (Gmail, Docs, Drive) is a SaaS example from Google.

ul.li: SaaS requires no infrastructure management from the customer.
Provider handles all updates, patches, and maintenance.
Subscription-based pricing model is common.
Examples: Google Workspace, Salesforce, Microsoft 365.

question.title: Public Cloud Benefits
question.scenario: A startup is evaluating whether to build their own datacenter or use public cloud services for their new application.
question.question-text: Which is a key benefit of using public cloud services compared to building your own datacenter?

choices.choice: No upfront capital investment and pay only for what you use
Complete physical control over all hardware
Guaranteed lowest possible cost in all scenarios
No need for any technical expertise

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Public cloud converts capital expenses to operational expenses with pay-as-you-go pricing.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Public cloud eliminates upfront capital expenditure (CapEx) for hardware. Instead, you pay operational expenses (OpEx) for what you consume. This improves cash flow, reduces financial risk, and allows scaling without large investments.

ul.li: CapEx to OpEx shift improves financial flexibility for businesses.
No need to predict capacity years in advance.
Economies of scale allow cloud providers to offer competitive pricing.
Focus spending on innovation rather than infrastructure maintenance.

question.title: Elasticity in Cloud Computing
question.scenario: An online retailer experiences 10x normal traffic during Black Friday sales events, then traffic returns to normal afterward.
question.question-text: Which cloud characteristic allows automatic scaling of resources up during peak demand and down when demand decreases?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Elasticity means resources automatically expand and contract based on demand.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Elasticity is the ability to automatically provision and deprovision resources to match demand. During peak traffic, more resources are added; during low traffic, resources are released. This ensures performance while optimizing costs.

ul.li: Elasticity differs from scalability: elasticity is automatic, scalability is the capability.
GCP services like Compute Engine autoscaling and App Engine automatic scaling provide elasticity.
Pay only for resources while they are running.
Essential for handling unpredictable or variable workloads.

question.title: High Availability
question.scenario: A financial services company requires their trading application to have minimal downtime, even if hardware fails in one location.
question.question-text: Which cloud characteristic ensures systems remain operational and accessible despite component failures?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: High availability means systems stay up and running even when failures occur.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: High availability (HA) is the ability of a system to remain operational with minimal downtime. This is achieved through redundancy, failover mechanisms, and distributing resources across multiple locations. GCP provides zones and regions for HA.

ul.li: HA is measured in uptime percentage (e.g., 99.9% = 8.76 hours downtime/year).
Deploying across multiple zones provides protection against zone failures.
GCP services like Cloud SQL offer HA configurations with automatic failover.
Design for failure: assume components will fail and build redundancy.

question.title: Horizontal vs Vertical Scaling
question.scenario: A web application needs to handle more traffic. The team is deciding between adding more servers or upgrading to a larger server.
question.question-text: What is the difference between horizontal scaling and vertical scaling?

choices.choice: Horizontal adds more instances; vertical increases the size/power of existing instances
Horizontal increases CPU; vertical increases memory
Horizontal is automatic; vertical is always manual
Horizontal is for storage; vertical is for compute

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Horizontal = more machines; Vertical = bigger machine.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Horizontal scaling (scale out/in) adds or removes instances to distribute load across multiple machines. Vertical scaling (scale up/down) increases or decreases the resources (CPU, memory) of a single instance. Horizontal scaling typically provides better fault tolerance.

ul.li: Horizontal scaling has no theoretical limit; vertical is limited by maximum machine size.
Horizontal requires applications to be designed for distributed processing.
Vertical scaling may require downtime to resize; horizontal usually does not.
GCP Managed Instance Groups enable automatic horizontal scaling.

question.title: Hybrid Cloud Model
question.scenario: A healthcare organization must keep patient data on-premises due to regulations but wants to use cloud for analytics workloads.
question.question-text: Which cloud deployment model combines on-premises infrastructure with public cloud services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Hybrid cloud connects on-premises and public cloud environments.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Hybrid cloud combines on-premises (or private cloud) infrastructure with public cloud services, allowing data and applications to move between them. This provides flexibility while meeting compliance requirements. Google Cloud offers Anthos for hybrid deployments.

ul.li: Hybrid requires secure connectivity between environments (VPN or dedicated interconnect).
Google Anthos enables consistent management across hybrid environments.
Common for regulated industries with data residency requirements.
Allows gradual cloud migration without full commitment.

question.title: Shared Responsibility Model
question.scenario: A company is deploying virtual machines on Google Compute Engine and wants to understand their security responsibilities.
question.question-text: In the cloud shared responsibility model for IaaS, what is the customer responsible for?

choices.choice: Operating system patches, application security, and data encryption
Physical datacenter security and hardware maintenance
Global network backbone and power supply

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: With IaaS, the customer manages security from the OS level up.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The shared responsibility model divides security duties between cloud provider and customer. For IaaS, Google secures the physical infrastructure, network, and virtualization. The customer secures the OS, middleware, applications, and data running on their VMs.

ul.li: Responsibility shifts based on service model: IaaS (customer manages most), PaaS (shared), SaaS (provider manages most).
Customer always responsible for: data classification, identity management, device security.
Google always responsible for: physical security, hardware, global infrastructure.
Understanding this model is critical for compliance and security planning.

question.title: GCP Global Infrastructure
question.scenario: A company wants to deploy their application close to customers in Asia, Europe, and North America for low latency.
question.question-text: What is a GCP region?

choices.choice: A specific geographic location containing multiple zones
A virtual network spanning the globe

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: A region is a geographic area containing multiple independent zones.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A GCP region is a specific geographic location (like us-central1 or europe-west1) that contains multiple zones. Regions are independent of each other and provide geographic isolation. Deploying in regions close to users reduces latency.

ul.li: GCP has 30+ regions worldwide with more being added.
Each region has at least 3 zones for high availability.
Some services are regional (within one region) or global (across regions).
Choose regions based on latency, compliance, and service availability.

question.title: GCP Zones
question.scenario: An architect is designing a highly available application and needs to understand how to protect against datacenter failures.
question.question-text: What is a GCP zone?

choices.choice: An isolated deployment area within a region with independent power and networking
A geographic continent where GCP operates
A security boundary for firewall rules

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: A zone is a single failure domain within a region.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A zone is a deployment area within a region with independent power, cooling, and networking. Zones are designed so that failures in one zone do not affect other zones. Deploying across multiple zones provides high availability within a region.

ul.li: Zone names follow the pattern: region-zone (e.g., us-central1-a, us-central1-b).
Resources like VMs are zonal - they exist in a specific zone.
Regional resources (like regional managed instance groups) span multiple zones.
Zone outages are isolated; other zones continue operating.

question.title: Google Cloud Console
question.scenario: A new cloud administrator needs to create and manage GCP resources without using command-line tools.
question.question-text: What is the Google Cloud Console?

choices.choice: A web-based graphical interface for managing GCP resources
A command-line tool installed on your computer
A mobile app for monitoring only
An API endpoint for programmatic access

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Console is the web-based UI for managing GCP.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Google Cloud Console is a web-based graphical user interface for managing GCP resources. It provides dashboards, resource management, monitoring, and access to all GCP services through a browser. Access it at console.cloud.google.com.

ul.li: Cloud Console includes Cloud Shell, a browser-based command line.
Provides project switching, resource search, and activity logging.
Includes IAM management, billing dashboards, and API explorer.
Alternative interfaces: gcloud CLI, Cloud APIs, Terraform.

question.title: Cloud Shell
question.scenario: A developer needs to run gcloud commands but does not have the SDK installed on their laptop.
question.question-text: What is Cloud Shell in GCP?

choices.choice: A browser-based command-line environment with pre-installed tools and temporary storage
A virtual machine you must provision and pay for
A desktop application for Windows only
A service for running shell scripts on a schedule

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Shell is a free, browser-based terminal with gcloud pre-installed.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Shell is a free, browser-based command-line environment accessible from the Cloud Console. It comes with the gcloud CLI, kubectl, and other tools pre-installed. It includes 5GB of persistent home directory storage.

ul.li: Cloud Shell runs on a temporary Compute Engine VM (resets after inactivity).
Home directory persists across sessions; other data does not.
Includes web preview for testing web applications.
Authenticated automatically to your Google account.

question.title: Compute Engine Overview
question.scenario: A company wants to run their existing Windows Server applications in GCP with full control over the operating system.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides virtual machines where you can install and configure your own operating system?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Compute Engine provides IaaS virtual machines in GCP.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Compute Engine is GCP's IaaS offering that provides virtual machines. You can choose machine type, operating system (Linux or Windows), storage, and networking configuration. You have full root/administrator access to manage the VMs.

ul.li: Multiple machine families: general-purpose, compute-optimized, memory-optimized.
Custom machine types allow precise CPU/memory configuration.
Supports preemptible/spot VMs for cost savings on fault-tolerant workloads.
Live migration keeps VMs running during host maintenance.

question.title: App Engine Overview
question.scenario: A developer wants to deploy a Python web application without managing servers, scaling, or load balancing.
question.question-text: Which GCP service is a fully managed platform for deploying web applications without infrastructure management?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: App Engine is GCP's PaaS for web applications.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: App Engine is a fully managed PaaS that handles infrastructure, scaling, and load balancing automatically. You deploy your code, and App Engine manages the rest. It supports multiple languages including Python, Java, Node.js, Go, and PHP.

ul.li: Two environments: Standard (sandbox, fast scaling) and Flexible (container-based, more control).
Automatic scaling based on traffic with scale-to-zero capability.
Built-in versioning and traffic splitting for A/B testing.
Integrated with Cloud Datastore, Cloud SQL, and other GCP services.

question.title: Cloud Storage Overview
question.scenario: A media company needs to store large video files that will be accessed from multiple applications and regions.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides scalable object storage for unstructured data like files and media?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Storage is GCP's object storage service for files and unstructured data.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Storage is a scalable, fully managed object storage service. It stores data as objects in buckets. Objects can be any type of file and are accessed via URLs or APIs. It offers multiple storage classes for different access patterns and cost optimization.

ul.li: Storage classes: Standard (frequent access), Nearline (monthly), Coldline (quarterly), Archive (yearly).
Objects are immutable; versioning tracks changes.
Strong global consistency for all operations.
Integrates with BigQuery, Dataflow, and other analytics services.

question.title: BigQuery Overview
question.scenario: A data analyst needs to run SQL queries on petabytes of data without managing any infrastructure.
question.question-text: Which GCP service is a serverless, fully managed data warehouse for analytics?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: BigQuery is GCP's serverless data warehouse for big data analytics.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: BigQuery is a serverless, highly scalable data warehouse that enables SQL queries on massive datasets. It separates storage and compute, allowing independent scaling. No infrastructure management is required, and you pay for queries run and data stored.

ul.li: Columnar storage format optimized for analytical queries.
Built-in machine learning with BigQuery ML.
Supports streaming inserts for real-time analytics.
Federated queries can access data in Cloud Storage, Bigtable, or external sources.

question.title: Cloud Functions
question.scenario: A developer wants to run a small piece of code that processes uploaded images without provisioning any servers.
question.question-text: Which GCP service allows running event-driven code without managing servers, billed only when code executes?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Functions is GCP's serverless, event-driven compute service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Functions is a serverless execution environment for building event-driven applications. Functions are triggered by events (HTTP requests, Cloud Storage uploads, Pub/Sub messages) and scale automatically. You pay only for execution time.

ul.li: Supports Node.js, Python, Go, Java, .NET, Ruby, and PHP.
Maximum execution time of 9 minutes (1st gen) or 60 minutes (2nd gen).
2nd generation built on Cloud Run provides more features.
Ideal for microservices, webhooks, and event processing.

question.title: Google Kubernetes Engine
question.scenario: A company wants to deploy containerized microservices with orchestration, scaling, and load balancing.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a managed Kubernetes environment for running containerized applications?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GKE is Google's managed Kubernetes service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) is a managed environment for deploying containerized applications using Kubernetes. Google manages the control plane, and you manage your containerized workloads. GKE handles scaling, updates, and cluster operations.

ul.li: Autopilot mode provides fully managed nodes; Standard mode offers more control.
Integrated with Cloud Logging, Monitoring, and Identity.
Supports hybrid deployments with Anthos.
Node auto-provisioning and auto-scaling optimize resource usage.

question.title: GCP Resource Hierarchy
question.scenario: A company is setting up their GCP environment and needs to understand how resources are organized.
question.question-text: What is the correct order of the GCP resource hierarchy from top to bottom?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Organization is at the top, Resources are at the bottom.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The GCP resource hierarchy has Organization at the top, followed by Folders (optional, for grouping), then Projects, and finally Resources at the bottom. IAM policies and organization policies inherit down this hierarchy.

ul.li: Organization is tied to a Google Workspace or Cloud Identity domain.
Folders can be nested up to 10 levels deep.
Projects are the primary unit for resource isolation and billing.
IAM permissions inherit downward but can be extended (not restricted) at lower levels.

question.title: GCP Projects
question.scenario: A team needs to create isolated environments for development, testing, and production workloads.
question.question-text: What is the purpose of a GCP project?

choices.choice: To organize resources, manage billing, and control access as an isolated environment
To define the physical location where resources run
To configure network routing between regions
To manage user passwords and authentication

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: A project is the basic unit for organizing GCP resources and billing.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A GCP project is a logical container that organizes all your GCP resources. It provides resource isolation, billing boundaries, and access control. Each resource belongs to exactly one project. Projects have a unique ID and number assigned by Google.

ul.li: Project ID is globally unique and immutable once set.
Project names are user-friendly labels that can be changed.
Each project is linked to a billing account for charges.
APIs are enabled per-project; enabling an API in one project does not affect others.

question.title: Project Identifiers
question.scenario: A developer is writing a script to access GCP APIs and needs to specify which project to use.
question.question-text: Which project identifier is globally unique, immutable, and commonly used in APIs and command-line tools?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Project ID is the human-readable, unique identifier used in commands and APIs.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Project ID is a globally unique, user-selected identifier that cannot be changed after creation. It is commonly used in gcloud commands, APIs, and URLs. Project Number is system-generated and also unique. Project Name is a display label that can be changed.

ul.li: Project ID: user-defined, globally unique, immutable (e.g., my-project-123).
Project Number: system-assigned, numeric, immutable (e.g., 123456789012).
Project Name: display name, can contain spaces, mutable.
Some APIs use Project Number internally even when you specify Project ID.

question.title: GCP Folders
question.scenario: An enterprise wants to organize projects by department (Engineering, Marketing, Finance) with different policies for each.
question.question-text: What is the purpose of folders in the GCP resource hierarchy?

choices.choice: To group projects and apply policies across multiple projects

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Folders organize projects and allow policy inheritance across groups.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Folders provide a grouping mechanism for projects within an organization. They allow you to organize projects by team, department, or environment and apply IAM and organization policies that inherit to all projects within the folder.

ul.li: Folders can be nested up to 10 levels for complex organizational structures.
IAM roles granted at the folder level inherit to all projects and resources below.
Organization policies at folder level override lower-level settings.
Folders require an organization resource; personal accounts cannot use folders.

question.title: Organization Resource
question.scenario: A large company wants centralized control over all GCP projects with organization-wide policies and access management.
question.question-text: What is required to have an Organization resource in GCP?

choices.choice: A Google Workspace or Cloud Identity domain

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Organization requires a Google Workspace or Cloud Identity domain.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: An Organization resource is automatically created when you have a Google Workspace or Cloud Identity domain. It provides the top-level node for the resource hierarchy, enabling centralized visibility and control over all GCP resources in your company.

ul.li: Cloud Identity Free provides organization features without Google Workspace.
Organization Admin role has full control over the organization.
Personal Gmail accounts cannot create organizations.
Projects not under an organization have limited governance capabilities.

question.title: Labels in GCP
question.scenario: A company needs to track which department owns each resource and allocate costs to the appropriate business unit.
question.question-text: What are labels used for in GCP?

choices.choice: To organize resources with key-value pairs for filtering, billing allocation, and automation
To define IAM permissions on resources
To specify the geographic region of resources
To encrypt data stored in resources

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Labels are key-value metadata attached to resources for organization and cost allocation.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Labels are key-value pairs attached to GCP resources. They help organize resources, filter in the console and CLI, allocate costs by category (cost centers, environments, teams), and automate operations. Labels do not affect resource behavior.

ul.li: Up to 64 labels per resource; keys and values are case-sensitive.
Common labels: environment (dev/prod), team, cost-center, application.
Labels appear in billing exports for cost analysis in BigQuery.
Different from tags, which are used for network firewall rules.

question.title: Enabling GCP APIs
question.scenario: A developer tries to use Cloud Vision API but receives an error that the API is not enabled.
question.question-text: What must you do before using a GCP service API in a project?

choices.choice: Enable the API in the project
Deploy the API to your VMs

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: APIs must be explicitly enabled in each project before use.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP APIs are disabled by default in new projects. You must enable each API you want to use in the project through the Cloud Console, gcloud CLI, or Terraform. This provides security and ensures you only pay for services you intend to use.

ul.li: Enable APIs via Console: APIs & Services > Enable APIs and Services.
CLI: gcloud services enable SERVICE_NAME
Some services automatically enable dependent APIs.
Organization policies can restrict which APIs can be enabled.

question.title: Cloud IAM Overview
question.scenario: An administrator needs to grant a developer access to create virtual machines but not delete them.
question.question-text: What does IAM stand for and what is its purpose in GCP?

choices.choice: Identity and Access Management - controls who can do what on which resources
Internet Access Module - manages network connectivity
Infrastructure Availability Monitor - tracks resource uptime

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IAM is Identity and Access Management for controlling resource access.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud IAM (Identity and Access Management) is GCP's system for controlling access to resources. It answers: Who (identity) can do What (permissions/roles) on Which resource (scope). IAM policies bind identities to roles at various levels of the resource hierarchy.

ul.li: IAM follows the principle of least privilege.
Policies are additive; there is no explicit deny.
IAM Conditions allow context-based access (time, IP, resource attributes).
Policy inheritance flows down the resource hierarchy.

question.title: IAM Principals
question.scenario: An application running on Compute Engine needs to access Cloud Storage without embedding credentials in code.
question.question-text: Which type of principal should be used to grant GCP service permissions to an application?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Service accounts provide identity for applications and services.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A service account is a special account for applications rather than users. Applications running on GCP can use attached service accounts for authentication. This avoids embedding credentials and allows fine-grained access control for automated processes.

ul.li: Default service accounts are created automatically for some services.
User-managed service accounts provide better security and control.
Service account keys should be avoided; use attached service accounts instead.
Workload Identity Federation allows external identities to impersonate service accounts.

question.title: IAM Roles
question.scenario: An administrator needs to grant a user permissions to manage Cloud Storage buckets without giving them access to other services.
question.question-text: What is an IAM role in GCP?

choices.choice: A collection of permissions that can be granted to identities
A user account in Google Workspace

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: A role is a bundle of permissions that you grant to principals.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: An IAM role is a collection of permissions. Permissions determine what operations are allowed on resources. You grant roles to principals (users, groups, service accounts) at a scope (organization, folder, project, or resource) to authorize access.

ul.li: Basic roles: Owner, Editor, Viewer (broad, not recommended).
Predefined roles: Fine-grained, service-specific (e.g., Storage Admin).
Custom roles: Create roles with specific permissions you define.
Permissions format: service.resource.verb (e.g., storage.buckets.create).

question.title: Predefined vs Basic Roles
question.scenario: A security team is reviewing access controls and wants to implement least privilege for GCP resources.
question.question-text: Why are predefined roles recommended over basic roles (Owner, Editor, Viewer)?

choices.choice: Predefined roles are more granular and follow least privilege principles
Basic roles are deprecated and will be removed
Predefined roles are free while basic roles cost extra
Basic roles only work at the organization level

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Predefined roles grant specific permissions; basic roles grant broad access.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Basic roles (Owner, Editor, Viewer) grant broad permissions across all services. Predefined roles are specific to services and grant only the permissions needed for particular tasks. Using predefined roles follows the principle of least privilege, improving security.

ul.li: Editor role includes thousands of permissions across all services.
Predefined roles like Compute Instance Admin focus on specific needs.
Basic roles can be restricted using IAM deny policies.
Organization policies can disable basic role grants.

question.title: IAM Policy Inheritance
question.scenario: A company grants the Storage Admin role to a user at the folder level. The folder contains multiple projects.
question.question-text: How does IAM policy inheritance work in GCP?

choices.choice: Policies inherit downward; permissions granted at higher levels apply to lower levels
Policies inherit upward; permissions granted at lower levels apply to higher levels
Policies do not inherit; each level is independent
Policies only inherit within the same region

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IAM policies flow downward through the resource hierarchy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: IAM policies inherit downward through the resource hierarchy: Organization to Folder to Project to Resource. A role granted at a higher level automatically applies to all resources below. Policies are additive; lower levels can add but not remove permissions.

ul.li: Effective policy = inherited policies + resource-level policy.
Cannot revoke inherited permissions at lower levels (without deny policies).
IAM deny policies can explicitly deny permissions (preview feature).
Grant roles at the narrowest scope needed for the task.

question.title: Google Groups for IAM
question.scenario: A team of 20 developers all need the same access to a project. Managing individual permissions is time-consuming.
question.question-text: What is the best practice for granting IAM permissions to multiple users who need the same access?

choices.choice: Create a Google Group, add users to it, and grant roles to the group
Grant roles to each user individually
Share a single service account among all users
Give everyone the Owner role for simplicity

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use Google Groups to manage permissions for multiple users efficiently.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Using Google Groups for IAM is a best practice. Add users to a group, then grant roles to the group. When team members join or leave, update the group membership rather than IAM policies. This simplifies management and reduces errors.

ul.li: Groups are managed in Google Workspace or Cloud Identity.
Nested groups are supported for complex organizational structures.
Audit group membership changes separately from IAM changes.
Group membership is evaluated at authorization time, not when policy is set.

question.title: Service Account Keys
question.scenario: A developer wants to run GCP commands from their local machine and is considering downloading a service account key file.
question.question-text: What is the security best practice regarding service account keys?

choices.choice: Avoid key files; use attached service accounts, Workload Identity, or gcloud authentication instead
Download keys for all service accounts for backup purposes
Share key files among team members for convenience
Store key files in source code repositories

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Service account keys are security risks; prefer alternatives like attached service accounts.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Service account key files are credentials that can be leaked or stolen. Best practice is to avoid them entirely. Use attached service accounts for GCP workloads, Workload Identity for GKE, or gcloud auth for development. If keys are necessary, rotate them regularly.

ul.li: Key files never expire unless explicitly deleted or rotated.
Organization policies can disable service account key creation.
Cloud Audit Logs track service account key usage.
Use Application Default Credentials (ADC) for local development.

question.title: GCP Billing Accounts
question.scenario: A company is starting with GCP and needs to understand how they will be charged for resource usage.
question.question-text: What is the purpose of a GCP billing account?

choices.choice: To link payment methods and pay for GCP resource usage in associated projects

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Billing accounts are linked to payment methods and charged for project usage.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A billing account defines who pays for GCP resources. It is linked to a payment method (credit card, bank account, or invoicing) and connected to one or more projects. All charges for resources in those projects are billed to the billing account.

ul.li: Projects must have a billing account to create resources that cost money.
Multiple projects can share a billing account.
Billing accounts can be linked to an organization for centralized management.
Billing Account Administrator role manages payment and billing settings.

question.title: GCP Free Tier
question.scenario: A student wants to learn GCP without incurring costs.
question.question-text: What does the GCP Free Tier provide?

choices.choice: Always Free products with monthly limits and a $300 credit for new users
Unlimited free usage of all GCP services
Free access only to documentation and training
A discount on enterprise support plans

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Free Tier includes Always Free products and $300 in credits for 90 days.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP Free Tier has two parts: Always Free products (limited monthly usage of services like f1-micro VM, Cloud Storage, BigQuery) that continue indefinitely, and a $300 credit for new users valid for 90 days to explore any GCP service.

ul.li: Always Free: 1 f1-micro VM (us regions), 5GB Cloud Storage, 1TB BigQuery queries/month.
Free trial credits cannot be used for cryptocurrency mining or certain services.
After trial, you must upgrade to a paid account to continue.
Budget alerts help avoid unexpected charges after free tier expires.

question.title: GCP Pricing Model
question.scenario: A company wants to understand how they will be charged for running virtual machines in GCP.
question.question-text: What pricing model does GCP primarily use for compute resources?

choices.choice: Pay-per-use with per-second billing for most compute resources
Fixed monthly fee regardless of usage
Free for the first year, then charged annually

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GCP charges for compute based on actual usage with per-second billing.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP uses a pay-per-use model where you are charged based on actual resource consumption. Compute Engine bills per second (minimum 1 minute). This means you only pay for what you use, and stopping resources stops charges (except for persistent storage).

ul.li: Per-second billing applies to Compute Engine, GKE, Dataproc, and more.
Storage is typically billed per GB-month.
Network egress is charged; ingress is usually free.
Pricing varies by region; some regions cost more than others.

question.title: Committed Use Discounts
question.scenario: A company has predictable compute workloads running 24/7 and wants to reduce costs.
question.question-text: What are Committed Use Discounts (CUDs) in GCP?

choices.choice: Discounts for committing to use specific resources for 1 or 3 years
Automatic discounts applied to all resources
Discounts for using resources only during off-peak hours

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: CUDs provide discounts for committing to resource usage over 1 or 3 years.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Committed Use Discounts (CUDs) offer significant savings (up to 57% for 3-year terms) in exchange for committing to use specific amounts of CPU, memory, or GPUs for 1 or 3 years. CUDs are ideal for predictable, steady-state workloads.

ul.li: Resource-based CUDs: commit to vCPU and memory amounts.
Spend-based CUDs: commit to spending on specific services.
CUDs apply automatically to eligible usage in the region.
Cannot be canceled; unused commitment is still charged.

question.title: Sustained Use Discounts
question.scenario: A company runs Compute Engine instances continuously throughout the month without any special commitments.
question.question-text: What are Sustained Use Discounts in GCP?

choices.choice: Automatic discounts for resources running more than 25% of the month
Discounts for new GCP customers only

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Sustained Use Discounts are automatic discounts for long-running resources.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Sustained Use Discounts (SUDs) are automatic discounts applied when you run Compute Engine resources for a significant portion of the month. Discounts increase as usage increases, up to 30% off for resources running the entire month. No commitment required.

ul.li: Applied automatically; no action needed.
Calculated based on incremental usage: 25%, 50%, 75%, 100% of month.
Applies to vCPUs and memory for general-purpose machine types.
Not available for E2 machine types or resources covered by CUDs.

question.title: Preemptible and Spot VMs
question.scenario: A company runs batch processing jobs that can tolerate interruptions and restart if needed.
question.question-text: What is the benefit of using Spot VMs (formerly Preemptible VMs) in GCP?

choices.choice: Up to 91% cost savings, but instances can be terminated with 30-second notice
Guaranteed uptime with premium support included
Free usage with no time limits

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Spot VMs are much cheaper but can be preempted when GCP needs capacity.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Spot VMs offer up to 60-91% discount compared to regular VMs. The trade-off is that GCP can terminate them with 30 seconds notice when capacity is needed. They are ideal for fault-tolerant, batch, or stateless workloads that can handle interruptions.

ul.li: Spot VMs are the new name; Preemptible VMs had 24-hour max runtime limit.
No SLA for availability; not suitable for production serving.
Use managed instance groups for automatic recreation after preemption.
Ideal for big data, CI/CD, rendering, and scientific computing.

question.title: GCP Pricing Calculator
question.scenario: A company wants to estimate their monthly GCP costs before deploying resources.
question.question-text: What tool can you use to estimate GCP costs before deploying resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: The Pricing Calculator helps estimate costs before deployment.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The GCP Pricing Calculator is a web-based tool that helps estimate costs for GCP services. You select services, configure specifications, and see estimated monthly costs. It helps with budgeting and comparing different configurations before committing resources.

ul.li: Access at cloud.google.com/products/calculator
Save and share estimates with stakeholders.
Includes all GCP services and pricing options.
Estimates are approximations; actual costs may vary.

question.title: Budgets and Alerts
question.scenario: A team wants to be notified when their GCP spending approaches a certain threshold to avoid unexpected charges.
question.question-text: What GCP feature allows you to set spending thresholds and receive notifications?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Budgets let you set spending limits and receive alerts at thresholds.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP Budgets allow you to set spending targets and configure alerts at percentage thresholds (e.g., 50%, 90%, 100%). Alerts can be sent via email, Pub/Sub, or trigger Cloud Functions for automated responses. Budgets help prevent unexpected charges.

ul.li: Budgets can be set per billing account, project, or filtered by label/service.
Alerts are notifications only; budgets do not automatically stop spending.
Use Pub/Sub and Cloud Functions to automate spending control actions.
Forecasted spend alerts predict if you will exceed budget.

question.title: Billing Export
question.scenario: A finance team needs to analyze detailed GCP spending data in their business intelligence tools.
question.question-text: How can you export detailed GCP billing data for analysis?

choices.choice: Export billing data to BigQuery or Cloud Storage
View in Cloud Console without export option

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Billing data can be exported to BigQuery for detailed analysis.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP allows exporting billing data to BigQuery for SQL-based analysis or to Cloud Storage as CSV/JSON files. BigQuery export includes detailed cost data with labels, enabling custom dashboards, cost allocation reports, and integration with BI tools.

ul.li: BigQuery export includes standard usage cost, detailed usage cost, and pricing data.
Historical data is available once export is enabled.
Use Data Studio (Looker Studio) for visualization.
Labels on resources appear in billing exports for cost allocation.

question.title: Cloud SQL
question.scenario: An application needs a managed relational database compatible with MySQL without managing database servers.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides fully managed relational databases for MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud SQL is GCP's managed relational database service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud SQL is a fully managed relational database service supporting MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server. Google manages backups, replication, patches, and updates. It offers high availability, automated failover, and integrates with other GCP services.

ul.li: High availability configuration provides 99.95% SLA.
Read replicas for scaling read operations.
Private IP for secure connectivity within VPC.
Automatic storage increase prevents out-of-space issues.

question.title: Virtual Private Cloud
question.scenario: A company needs to create an isolated network environment for their GCP resources with control over IP addressing.
question.question-text: What is a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) in GCP?

choices.choice: A software-defined network providing connectivity for GCP resources
A physical datacenter dedicated to one customer
A storage bucket with private access

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC is a virtual network for connecting and isolating GCP resources.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A VPC is a global, software-defined network that provides connectivity for Compute Engine VMs, GKE clusters, and other resources. VPCs allow you to define IP ranges, subnets, routes, and firewall rules. VPCs are global but contain regional subnets.

ul.li: GCP VPCs are global; subnets are regional and span zones.
Auto mode VPCs create subnets automatically; custom mode gives full control.
VPC peering connects VPCs; Shared VPC centralizes network management.
Private Google Access allows VMs without external IPs to reach Google APIs.

question.title: Cloud Monitoring
question.scenario: An operations team needs to track the performance and health of their GCP resources and applications.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides metrics, dashboards, and alerting for monitoring resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Monitoring collects metrics and provides dashboards and alerts.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Monitoring (part of Google Cloud Operations Suite) collects metrics, events, and metadata from GCP resources, AWS, and on-premises systems. It provides dashboards for visualization and alerting policies to notify you of issues.

ul.li: Integrated with Cloud Logging for unified observability.
Custom metrics can be created for application-specific data.
Uptime checks monitor external endpoints.
Alert policies can notify via email, SMS, Slack, PagerDuty, etc.

question.title: Cloud Logging
question.scenario: A security team needs to collect and analyze logs from all GCP resources for compliance and troubleshooting.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides centralized log management and analysis?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Logging collects and stores logs from GCP resources.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Logging (part of Google Cloud Operations Suite) is a fully managed service for storing, searching, analyzing, and alerting on log data. It automatically collects logs from GCP services and allows ingestion of custom application logs.

ul.li: Log Router directs logs to storage destinations (buckets, BigQuery, Pub/Sub).
Log-based metrics create custom metrics from log entries.
Audit Logs track admin activity and data access.
Retention periods are configurable; default is 30 days.

question.title: Organization Policies
question.scenario: A security administrator wants to enforce that no one can create resources outside of approved regions.
question.question-text: What GCP feature allows administrators to set constraints on resource configurations across the organization?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Organization policies enforce constraints on how resources can be configured.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Organization Policy Service allows administrators to set constraints that control resource configurations. Unlike IAM (who can do what), organization policies control what can be done (e.g., restrict resource locations, disable service account key creation, require encryption).

ul.li: Constraints can allow, deny, or require specific configurations.
Policies inherit down the hierarchy; can be overridden at lower levels if allowed.
Common constraints: gcp.resourceLocations, iam.disableServiceAccountKeyCreation.
Custom constraints allow organization-specific requirements.

question.title: Disaster Recovery
question.scenario: A company needs to ensure their critical applications can recover quickly if an entire region becomes unavailable.
question.question-text: What is the best approach for disaster recovery across GCP regions?

choices.choice: Deploy resources in multiple regions with data replication and failover mechanisms
Rely on single-region deployment with extra VMs
Use only local backups on the same disk
Disable automatic updates to prevent failures

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Multi-region deployment provides protection against regional failures.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Disaster recovery requires deploying resources across multiple regions with data replication. If one region fails, traffic can failover to another region. GCP offers multi-region storage, Cloud SQL cross-region replicas, and global load balancing for this purpose.

ul.li: RTO (Recovery Time Objective): How quickly to recover.
RPO (Recovery Point Objective): How much data loss is acceptable.
Hot standby: Full duplicate running; Cold standby: Resources deployed when needed.
Multi-region Cloud Storage classes provide automatic replication.

question.title: GCP Support Plans
question.scenario: A company is evaluating GCP and wants to understand what support options are available.
question.question-text: What support options does Google Cloud provide?

choices.choice: Free basic support, plus paid tiers (Standard, Enhanced, Premium) with faster response times
Only premium paid support with 24/7 phone access
Community forums only with no official support
Support is included free for all customers at all levels

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GCP offers free basic support and multiple paid support tiers.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP provides Basic support (free, documentation and community), Standard support (paid, business hours support), Enhanced support (paid, faster response, 24/7 for critical issues), and Premium support (paid, dedicated TAM, fastest response). Higher tiers offer faster response times and more services.

ul.li: Basic: Self-service documentation, billing support, community forums.
Standard: Unlimited cases, 4-hour response for P2 issues.
Enhanced: 1-hour response for P1, proactive guidance.
Premium: 15-minute response for P1, Technical Account Manager, training credits.

term.name: Cloud Computing
term.definition: The on-demand delivery of IT resources over the internet with pay-as-you-go pricing, eliminating the need to own and maintain physical datacenters and servers.
term.exam-note: NIST defines 5 characteristics: on-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling, rapid elasticity, measured service.

term.name: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
term.definition: Cloud service model providing virtualized computing resources where the customer manages OS, middleware, runtime, and applications.
term.exam-note: Compute Engine is GCP's primary IaaS offering. Maximum control, maximum responsibility.

term.name: Platform as a Service (PaaS)
term.definition: Cloud service model providing a platform for developing and deploying applications without managing underlying infrastructure.
term.exam-note: App Engine and Cloud Run are GCP PaaS offerings. Focus on code, not infrastructure.

term.name: Software as a Service (SaaS)
term.definition: Cloud service model delivering complete software applications over the internet, accessed through web browsers without installation.
term.exam-note: Google Workspace (Gmail, Docs, Drive) is Google's SaaS offering. Minimal customer responsibility.

term.name: Region
term.definition: A specific geographic location containing multiple zones where GCP resources can be deployed.
term.exam-note: Regions are independent; choose based on latency, compliance, and service availability. Examples: us-central1, europe-west1.

term.name: Zone
term.definition: An isolated deployment area within a region with independent power, cooling, and networking infrastructure.
term.exam-note: Deploy across multiple zones for high availability. Zone format: region-zone (e.g., us-central1-a).

term.name: Project
term.definition: The base-level organizing entity in GCP that contains resources, manages billing, and controls access.
term.exam-note: Every resource belongs to exactly one project. Project ID is globally unique and immutable.

term.name: Organization
term.definition: The root node of the GCP resource hierarchy, representing a company and providing centralized visibility and control.
term.exam-note: Requires Google Workspace or Cloud Identity domain. Enables organization policies and centralized IAM.

term.name: Folder
term.definition: An optional grouping mechanism in the resource hierarchy for organizing projects by team, department, or environment.
term.exam-note: IAM and organization policies set at folder level inherit to all contained projects.

term.name: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
term.definition: GCP's system for controlling who (identity) can do what (permissions) on which resources (scope).
term.exam-note: Policies are additive with no explicit deny. Use predefined roles over basic roles for least privilege.

term.name: IAM Role
term.definition: A collection of permissions that can be granted to principals (users, groups, service accounts) at a scope.
term.exam-note: Three types: Basic (broad), Predefined (service-specific), Custom (user-defined).

term.name: Service Account
term.definition: A special account used by applications and services (not humans) to authenticate and access GCP resources.
term.exam-note: Avoid key files; use attached service accounts. Default service accounts have broad permissions.

term.name: Billing Account
term.definition: A payment entity linked to one or more projects that defines who pays for GCP resource usage.
term.exam-note: Projects need a billing account to use paid services. One billing account can link to many projects.

term.name: Compute Engine
term.definition: GCP's IaaS service providing virtual machines with customizable configurations running on Google infrastructure.
term.exam-note: Offers preemptible/spot VMs for cost savings, custom machine types, and live migration during maintenance.

term.name: App Engine
term.definition: GCP's fully managed PaaS for building and deploying web applications without managing infrastructure.
term.exam-note: Two environments: Standard (sandbox, fast scaling) and Flexible (container-based). Supports multiple languages.

term.name: Cloud Storage
term.definition: GCP's unified object storage service for storing and accessing unstructured data like files, images, and backups.
term.exam-note: Four storage classes: Standard, Nearline, Coldline, Archive. Objects stored in buckets.

term.name: BigQuery
term.definition: GCP's serverless, highly scalable data warehouse for running SQL queries on massive datasets.
term.exam-note: Separates storage and compute. Supports streaming and batch. Includes BigQuery ML for machine learning.

term.name: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
term.definition: A global, software-defined network providing connectivity, isolation, and security for GCP resources.
term.exam-note: VPCs are global; subnets are regional. Auto mode creates subnets automatically; custom mode for full control.

term.name: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE)
term.definition: GCP's managed Kubernetes service for deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications.
term.exam-note: Autopilot mode fully manages nodes; Standard mode offers more control. Integrated with Google Cloud services.

term.name: Cloud Functions
term.definition: GCP's serverless, event-driven compute service for running code in response to events without managing servers.
term.exam-note: Pay only for execution time. Triggered by HTTP, Pub/Sub, Cloud Storage events. 2nd gen built on Cloud Run.
